posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
I have recently created the first mini Romi swerve bot. My goal is to build a smaller version of our current drive train to teach others how to program it. I am using YAGSL so I want to use the same library on this bot. I encountered an issue with the quadrature encoders on the Romi’s. I configured the pins to DIO and created a command to read them, which worked well. However, when trying to get raw encoder values, I only received zeros. I need suggestions to fix this.

link_counts.title: Pololu - Magnetic Encoder Pair Kit for Micro Metal Gearmotors, 12 CPR, 2.7-18V

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I suspect that you would need to make custom Romi firmware to support more than the 2 encoders.

posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked: I’ve never done anything like that before, is there some guide I could follow? Or is there a better alternative out there that’s not too bulky?

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: The XRP board supports 4 encoders natively; the XRP Differential Swerve Drive Robot offers 100% plastic modules and is mostly printed, along with downloading free STL models.

link_counts.title: XRP Differential Swerve Drive Robot! by Jacob Williams | Download free STL model | Printables.com
Omnidirectional XRP Robot by WildWilly | Download free STL model | Printables.com

posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked: I can use the onboard motor controllers to control the azimuth motors and then use the DIO ports for direction and pulse width modulation for the speed. I just need to figure out how to do digital outputs for the board in WPILib Java. I also need to figure out how to use the PWM port directly without the Servo class thingy. I’ll do some more research.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: If you end up buying any I believe there is still a substantial 50% discount for FRC teams.

posts.name: Martin
posts.cooked: I would love to see this since I’ve always been interested in doing it for fun. It can also assist in teaching eager newcomers how to program swerve without requiring a large, full-sized robot.

The user discovered a thread about a project involving the Romi, which initially had limitations due to its restricted encoder ports and an uncalibrated gyro causing significant drift, hindering advanced projects like autonomous navigation. Switching to the XRP platform, the user tested it and found it promising—its gyro performed exceptionally well in x/y axes with minimal drift, though there was a slight (~3 degrees) drift in the z-axis over 2.5 minutes. The XRP platform allows for swerve movement using two diagonal swerve units and two roller balls as casters, leaving two motor ports free for drive wheels with encoders. This setup enables distance-based autonomous navigation. With a reliable gyro, the platform ensures consistent field-centric control during the 2.5-minute game period.
